awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A Robust Indoor Localization System For Mobile Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to provide accurate indoor location services to users via existing mobile electronic devices like smartphones and tablets. This technology will bring many of the applications powered by GPS, like navigation, tracking and location-based advertising to indoor markets. We propose using a hybrid ultrasound and RF-based beaconing system to enable sub-20cm location accuracy within large, GPS-denied environments. Our approach is unique in that it is compatible with current smartphones by simply downloading an app. The system uses an infrastructure comprised of beacons, which can be powered through indoor solar energy-harvesting instead of requiring expensive electrical wiring. Accurate indoor location-aware mobile applications can enhance applications ranging from retail, healthcare and manufacturing, all the way to building navigation, asset tracking and aiding the visually impaired.

The proposed project aims to develop a robust localization platform which can localize off-the-shelf devices like smartphones and tablets as well as low-cost radio frequency (RF) tags to better than 20cm accuracy in indoor locations that do not have access to GPS. Current indoor localization technologies for smartphones often fall short in terms of accuracy, especially in highly dynamic environments with obstructions. Our system utilizes energy harvesting beacons with an array of speakers to transmit time-of-flight ranging signals in the near-ultrasound spectrum. These signals can be recorded and demodulated in software by commodity smartphones, while being inaudible to humans. The research in this phase will aim to develop the methods and technologies required to streamline installation to support large facilities like airports and convention centers that would require tens to hundreds of beacons. This involves the development of a mapping and commissioning system as well as hardware beacon modules for integration of our technology into the products of third parties (e.g. smart camera systems, building sensors, etc). We will also integrate the ability to track tagged assets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Yodel Labs is a company specializing in indoor localization technologies with an emphasis on mobile device solutions. The company was founded to commercialize a ground breaking new localization system that enables highly accurate localization of off-the-shelf smartphones and tablets. This system is called the Acoustic Location Processing System (ALPS) and uses a combination of ultrasound ranging and sensor fusion techniques to achieve a localization error of <25cm (90th percentile), even in cluttered environments. It is a beacon-based system, where time synchronized beacons emit both Bluetooth, as well as ultrasound ranging signals that are imperceptible to humans, but detectable by mobile devices. ALPS measures the Time of Flight (TOF) of the ultrasound signals to calculate the ranges to nearby beacons and the location of the mobile device. It employs advanced filtering, as well as inertial and optionally visual sensor fusion techniques to achieve industry leading accuracy, robustness and acquisition time. ALPS also supports high accuracy localization of low-power, Ultra-Wide-Band-based (UWB) asset tags, to enable the tracking of mobile objects like heavy machinery.

ALPS is the foundation for a complementary technology called the ALPS Camera Fusion System, which enables real-time, automatic classification (e.g. employee, visitor, etc.) and identification of people and objects (e.g. forklifts) in security camera feeds, without the use of controversial facial recognition technology. Instead, the system employs state-of-the-art sensor fusion algorithms to combine anonymous, video-based tracking data with ALPS location data from smartphones and asset tags, carried by some or all of these people and objects.

One of the primary applications of the ALPS Camera Fusion System is automatic access control and intrusion detection for restricted areas, based on video surveillance and person identity or classification. Current video-based intrusion detection systems cannot differentiate between authorized and unauthorized people without using facial recognition technologies, resulting in high false alarm rates that are prone to overwhelming security system operators. Yodel Labs? system has consistently shown true positive and true negative rates of people classification and identification in excess of 96%, drastically reducing false intrusion alarms. Additional applications of the system include the reduction of camera tracking failures (e.g. due to obstructions), workplace safety applications like worker-forklift proximity alerting, and automatic filtering of undesired video analytics data like employee movements in retail customer analytics datasets.
During Phase II of our SBIR grant we were addressing several key objectives to commercialize ALPS. These objectives were:

  1. To integrate ALPS with real-time camera-based people and object tracking data in order to identify and classify the tracked people and objects, creating the ALPS Camera Fusion System.
  2. To create a streamlined automatic commissioning system, which enables rapid mapping and automatic setup of ALPS beacons. This allows installers to rapidly and cost-effectively deploy the system with minimal training.
  3. To integrate our Ultra-Wide-Band (UWB) ALPS asset tags with ALPS beacons, allowing for hybrid ultrasound and UWB localization of smartphones and tags. ALPS asset tags enable the tracking of mobile objects that would impractical to track via smartphones.

We were successful in delivering results for each of these objectives and have continuously refined our business plan through extensive piloting of our systems with various customers. This Phase II award allowed us to develop the ALPS Camera Fusion System and has subsequently opened opportunities for ALPS technology in security, safety and other unique applications that were not known to us before. We are continuing to pursue technical and business development related to the above objectives to further improve upon the technologies developed during this award and are confident to have found a sustainable path forward for commercializing our products.


Last Modified: 11/20/2023
Modified by: Patrick Lazik
